bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built between 1859 and 1861, Alumni Hall is one of the three oldest buildings on the original campus. Alumni Hall originally housed the Chapel until the present Chapel was completed in 1918, and then the space was converted into classroom space. In 1965 a $600,000 renovation project was underway to modernize the interior.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Gift of James B. Colgate and named William Colgate Memorial Hall to honor his parents. Built in 1874 to house the preparatory school, Colgate Academy. When the Academy was closed in 1912, the building became the Administration Building until 1963, when the building was destroyed by a fire.

did.unittitle: Photos - Students and people in front of Colgate Academy
Old Administration Building, including Taylor Lake
Landscape views including Old Administration Building/Colgate Academy
"Records Salvage After the Fire at Colgate University"

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Gift of James B. Colgate, built in 1890 to house Colgateâ€™s Library. Edwin A. Quick was the architect of the project. In the summer of 1958, all books and library materials were moved to the new Case Library Building. The Romance language department used the space until 1964. After renovations, the James B. Colgate building became the new Administrative Building (replacing the former administration building, William Colgate Memorial Hall, which had been destroyed by a fire in 1963).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes photocopies of original court proceedings. The originals are held at the Madison County Courthouse in Wampsville, New York.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built in 1959 and named after Colgateâ€™s ninth president Edward Needham Case in 1962, the architect of the project was Robert B. Oâ€™Conner. In 1981 the building was renovated and expanded, and another major renovation project was completed in 2007.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Completed in 1967, the Oâ€™Conner campus center and bookstore was built to replace the James C. Colgate Student Union center and the former Campus store and snackbar located in the basement of East Hall

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built in 1918. The Chapel organ was added in 1975.

did.unittitle: O.C. Stanley photos, mounted on cardboard
Draft and Speech, Miss Mary Colgate at Chapel dedication

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built in 1959 to provide a space for meditation, prayer, and religious study through personal experience, it is the first building of its kind on an American college campus.

did.unittitle: Renovations to Cooley Science Library - Project Manual

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Building began in the summer of 1964 for what was a much needed space to accommodate the creative arts- art, music, performance, at Colgate. In 1979, the Eric J. Ryan Studio Center was added and named in memory of the Fine Arts instructor who passed away in 1971.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Hascall Hall was built in 1884 as a new laboratory for the Science department and came to be referred to as the Biology Building. The architect was C.B. Cutler from Troy, NY. The building was expanded and doubled in size in 1906. In the late 1960s, the administration attempted to raze the building and replace it with the Olin Life Science Building (to be built adjacent). Instead, the friends of the â€œOld Bioâ€ building petitioned to save the building and it was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1973. The building was renovated in 1978 and renamed Hascall Hall after Daniel Hascall, one of the original 13 founders of Colgate. Hascall Hall became the home of the Philosophy and Religion Department.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Old Gymnasium refers to the building completed in 1894, where the James C. Colgate Student Union is currently located. Plans for a new gymnasium began in 1924 and the old gym was to be converted into a Student Union. But the building was destroyed by a fire in 1926, just before the new Huntington gym was completed. Huntington Gym, built in 1926, New York architect Franklin B. Ware, named after â€œDocâ€ Huntington (Dr. Ellery Channing), who was known for his involvement with Colgate athletics.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built 1905-1906 to house the natural sciences. In 1971 the building was remodeled and enlarged for the geology, physics and astronomy departments.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built in 1926 Lawrence Hall served as a recitation center until it became used for the Classics, Romance languages and literature, Education, English and German. The building was renovated in 1964.

did.unittitle: Correspondence, President George B. Cutten regarding Lawrence Hall

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Completed in 1930 and named after Chemistry Professor Dr. Joseph Frank McGregory to accommodate lab work, instruction and research in chemistry. The George R. Cooley Science Library was added in 1981.

did.unittitle: Floor Plans and Dedication of George R. Cooley Science Library

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built in 1900 for the residence of President George Edmands Merrill, the house remained the Presidentâ€™s residence until 1962 when then president Vincent Barnett Jr. moved into Watson House. Merrill house was then converted into a Faculty Club.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built in 1970, the Olin Life Sciences Building provided much needed laboratory and instruction space for the sciences and research.

did.unittitle: Photographs - Convocation - Mr. Horn of the Olin Foundation
Local Publications regarding Olin Life Sciences building
Specifications for the Construction of Olin Life Science Building
Specifications for the Construction of Olin Life Science Building
Payne House (Home of Samuel Payne) - site of DKE House
Payne's Creek and Oak Drive Bridge

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built in 1959 and designed by Oscar F. Wiggins (Class of 1922), Reid Athletic Center includes the basketball facilities, Cotterell Court and the Howard Starr Hockey Rink, in addition to bowling alleys, team rooms, a training room and offices.

did.unittitle: Proposed Colgate University Golf Course Plans

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built in 1927 and designed by Walter B. Chambers, Stillman Hall provides living space along with study space and a lounge for freshmen.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Spear House was built in 1835 as a faculty residence and in 1935 was remodeled and converted to a house for the Samuel Colgate Baptist Historical Collection. Named for Professor of Hebrew and Secretary and Treasurer of the University who lived here with his family, Spear House was then used by Lambda Chi Alpha Fraternity, then housed the Director of Placement, Dean of Residences, University Counselor and WRCU. Today, Spear House is the home of Career Services.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built in 1937, the James C. Colgate Student Union was built to foster social life on campus and included dining facilities, a game room, and several lounges for meetings of student groups. The building now houses the offices of student organizations, Donovanâ€™s Pub and the Hall of Presidents.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built by President Stephen W. Taylor and purchased by the University in 1891, after which Taylor Hall was used by the fraternities of Colgate Academy, then served as YMCA headquarters, University Post Office and Faculty Club.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built in 1901 to create more space for ice skating, Taylor Lake has become intertwined with many Colgate traditions such as the Torchlight Procession the evening before Commencement and the presence of the Swans.

did.unittitle: Photographs - Taylor Lake, Benches, Aerial views

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Built in 1827 by Daniel Hascall, West Hall is the oldest building on campus. The chapel was located here until 1867. Renovated in 1910 and 1954.
